triples.name: Randomized experiment
triples.relevance: The paper employs large-scale randomized experiments to test causal relationships between weak ties and job mobility.

triples.name: Causal inference
triples.relevance: The paper uses causal inference methodology to establish that weak ties causally influence job mobility.

triples.name: LinkedIn
triples.relevance: LinkedIn is the platform where the experiments were conducted, providing data on over 20 million users' network changes.

triples.name: Interpersonal ties
triples.relevance: The paper tests weak interpersonal ties as the core concept, extending Mark Granovetter's seminal theory.

triples.name: Labor mobility
triples.relevance: Job mobility (a form of labor mobility) is the primary outcome variable measured in the experiments.

triples.name: Social network
triples.relevance: Social networks and their structure are the fundamental context within which the paper analyzes tie strength effects.

triples.name: Social network analysis
triples.relevance: The paper uses social network analysis techniques to measure tie strength through interaction intensity and mutual connections.

triples.name: Nonlinear relationship
triples.relevance: The paper proposes a novel nonlinear (inverted U-shaped) relationship between tie strength and job transmission, revising prior linear assumptions.
